question:
Question 1 In the pin-jointed truss shown in the figure, the members that carry zero force are identified.
Which of the following options is/are zero-force members?
solution: To identify zero-force members, we use the following rules: Rule 1: If two non-collinear members meet at a joint unstressed by an external force or support, then both members are zero-force members. Rule 2: If three members form a truss joint and two of them are collinear, the third member is a zero-force member provided no external load or support reaction is applied at that joint. Apply Rule 1: At joint B, members BC and BD meet, and there is no external load or support at B. By Rule 1, [latex]\text{BC is a zero-force member}[/latex]. Apply Rule 1 again: At joint J, members JK and JL meet, with no external force or support. By Rule 1, [latex]\text{JK is a zero-force member}[/latex]. Final Answer: [latex]\text{Zero-force members are: BC and JK}[/latex]

question: Question 2 The figure shows a propped cantilever with uniform flexural rigidity [latex]EI[/latex] (in [latex]\text{N} \cdot \text{m}^2[/latex]) and subjected to a moment [latex]M[/latex] (in [latex]\text{N} \cdot \text{m}[/latex]). Consider forces and displacements in the upward direction as positive. Find the upward reaction at the propped support B (in N) when this support settles by [latex](-\Delta )[/latex], given in metres.
solution:
We use the principle of superposition: Reaction at B due to [latex]M[/latex] only: [latex]\frac{3M}{2L}[/latex] Reaction at B due to downward settlement [latex]-\Delta[/latex]: [latex]+\frac{3EI \Delta}{L^3}[/latex] Total reaction at B:
[latex]
R_B = \frac{3M}{2L} - \frac{3EI \Delta}{L^3}
[/latex]

question: Question 3 Consider the pin-jointed truss shown in the figure. Influence line is drawn for the axial force in the member G-L when a unit load travels on the bottom chord of the truss. Identify the CORRECT influence line from the following options: Note: Positive value corresponds to tension and negative value corresponds to compression in the member.
solution: To determine the correct influence line for axial force in member GL: Step 1: Member G-L is a diagonal member connecting the bottom chord joint G to the top chord joint L. It is part of a vertical and diagonal web system in a pin-jointed truss. Step 2: Apply a unit moving load on the bottom chord and analyze the influence of this load on the axial force in member G-L. When the unit load is directly under joint G, it induces the maximum positive influence (tension) in member G-L. When the unit load is under joint L, it causes a negative influence (compression). Between G and L, the influence is linear due to statically determinate nature of the truss and linear response of the system. Outside G and L (i.e., A-G and L-P), the influence is zero since the load does not affect the member significantly. Step 3: From the options, only Option (D) correctly shows: A positive peak (1.33) under G A negative value under L Zero elsewhere Final Answer: [latex] \boxed{\text{Option (D)}} [/latex]

question: Question 4 In the rigid-jointed frame shown in the figure, the distribution factor of the member [latex]A D[/latex] is closest to
solution: To find the distribution factor of the member AD at joint A, we use the formula: [latex]\text{Distribution Factor (DF)} = \frac{\text{Stiffness of Member}}{\text{Sum of Stiffnesses at the Joint}}[/latex] We need the stiffness of all members connected at joint A: Members connected at A: AD, AC, and AF. All are fixed at far ends, so stiffness for each is: [latex]K = \frac{4EI}{L}[/latex] (for member with far end fixed) From the figure: For AD: Length = [latex]\frac{L}{2}[/latex], Flexural Rigidity = [latex]EI[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow K_{AD} = \frac{4EI}{L/2} = \frac{8EI}{L}[/latex] For AC: Length = [latex]L[/latex], Flexural Rigidity = [latex]2EI[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow K_{AC} = \frac{4(2EI)}{L} = \frac{8EI}{L}[/latex] For AF: Length = [latex]L[/latex], Flexural Rigidity = [latex]2EI[/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow K_{AF} = \frac{4(2EI)}{L} = \frac{8EI}{L}[/latex] Total stiffness at A: [latex]K_{\text{total}} = K_{AD} + K_{AC} + K_{AF} = \frac{8EI}{L} + \frac{8EI}{L} + \frac{8EI}{L} = \frac{24EI}{L}[/latex] Distribution factor for AD: [latex]DF_{AD} = \frac{K_{AD}}{K_{\text{total}}} = \frac{8EI/L}{24EI/L} = \frac{1}{3}[/latex] Final Answer: [latex]\boxed{\frac{1}{3}}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Consider the frame shown in the figure under the loading of [latex]100 \mathrm{kN} . \mathrm{m}[/latex] couples at the joints [latex]B[/latex] and [latex]G[/latex]. Considering only the effects of flexural deformations, which of the following statements is/are true:
solution: Step 1: Analyze the structure - It's a symmetric frame with members: AB, BC, CD, DE, EF, and FG. - Moments of [latex]100 \, \text{kN} \cdot \text{m}[/latex] are applied at joints B and G (clockwise and counterclockwise respectively). - All vertical columns (AB, DE, FG) have different stiffnesses as per EI values. - Assume fixed supports at A, D, and F. Step 2: Moment Distribution - focus on joints B, C, and D Let's denote member stiffness factors: - Stiffness of member BC from joint B is: [latex] K_{BC} = \frac{4EI}{L} = \frac{4EI}{6} = \frac{2EI}{3} [/latex] - Stiffness of member AB from joint B: [latex] K_{BA} = \frac{2EI}{6} = \frac{EI}{3} [/latex] Distribution Factor (DF) at Joint B: [latex] DF_{BC} = \frac{K_{BC}}{K_{BA} + K_{BC}} = \frac{\frac{2EI}{3}}{\frac{EI}{3} + \frac{2EI}{3}} = \frac{2}{3} [/latex] [latex] DF_{BA} = \frac{1}{3} [/latex] Similarly at Joint C (connecting BC, CD, and CE): All members have same length and stiffness [latex]2EI[/latex], so: [latex] K_{CB} = \frac{4EI}{6} = \frac{2EI}{3} [/latex] [latex] K_{CD} = \frac{2EI}{8} = \frac{EI}{4} [/latex] [latex] DF_{CB} = \frac{\frac{2EI}{3}}{\frac{2EI}{3} + \frac{EI}{4}} = \frac{8}{11} [/latex] [latex] DF_{CD} = \frac{3}{11} [/latex] Step 3: Apply the moment at B and perform moment distribution - Moment at B = [latex]100 \, \text{kN} \cdot \text{m}[/latex] (clockwise), so fixed-end moment to BC is [latex]+100[/latex] - Apply moment distribution considering carry-over and distribution factors. After a few iterations (or by symmetry), we get: [latex] M_{BC} = 50 \, \text{kN} \cdot \text{m} [/latex] [latex] M_{CB} = 50 \, \text{kN} \cdot \text{m} [/latex] Because of symmetric load and structure, the moment gets equally distributed between BC and CD. Conclusion: - Moment at joint C is exactly [latex]50 \, \text{kN} \cdot \text{m}[/latex], not more. - Thus, option D ("more than 50") is False . - Joint C has no rotation due to symmetry - option C is True . - CD has zero axial force and zero shear since there?s no direct force acting - options A and B are True .

options.A: Axial force is zero in the member CD
options.B: Shear force is zero in the member CD
options.C: There is no rotation in the joint C
options.D: The magnitude of bending moment developed in the member BC at the end C is more than [latex]50 \mathrm{kN} . \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question: Question 10 Muller-Breslau principle is used in analysis of structures for
solution: Muller Breslass principle is used to draw influence line diagram for determinate and indeterminate structures. question:
Question 14 The linearly elastic planar structure shown in the figure is acted upon by two
vertical concentrated forces. The horizontal beams UV and WX are connected
with the help of the vertical linear spring with spring constant k = 20 kN/m. The
fixed supports are provided at U and X. It is given that flexural rigidity
 [latex]EI = 10^5 kN-m^2, P = 100 kN,[/latex] and [latex]a = 5 m[/latex]. Force Q is applied at the center of beam WX such that the force in the spring VW becomes zero. The magnitude of force Q (in kN) is ________. (round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
If force in spring is zero, there will be no
deformation in spring i.e., deflection of point V
will be equal to deflection of point W [latex] \begin{aligned}
\delta _v&=\delta _w\\
\frac{P(2a)^3}{3EI}&=\frac{Q(a)^3}{3(2EI)}+\frac{Q(a)^2}{2(2EI)}
+a\\
\frac{8}{3}P&=\left ( \frac{1}{6}+\frac{1}{4} \right )Q\\
Q&=\frac{32}{5}P=640kN
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 15 Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct?

options.A:
If a linearly elastic structure is subjected to a set of loads, the partial derivative
of the total strain energy with respect to the deflection at any point is equal to
the load applied at that point.
options.B:
If a linearly elastic structure is subjected to a set of loads, the partial derivative
of the total strain energy with respect to the load at any point is equal to the
deflection at that point.
options.C:
If a structure is acted upon by two force system Pa and Pb , in equilibrium
separately, the external virtual work done by a system of forces Pb during the
deformations caused by another system of forces Pa is equal to the external
virtual work done by the Pa system during the deformation caused by the Pb
system.
options.D:
The shear force in a conjugate beam loaded by the M/EI diagram of the real

beam is equal to the corresponding deflection of the real beam.

Question 17 Consider a simply supported beam PQ as shown in the figure. A truck having
100 kN on the front axle and 200 kN on the rear axle, moves from left to right.
The spacing between the axles is 3 m. The maximum bending moment at point
R is ______ kNm. (in integer)
solution:
[latex]\frac{ab}{L}=\frac{1 \times 4}{5}=0.8m[/latex] To get maximum BN at R [latex]\begin{aligned}
BM_{max}&=200 \times \frac{ab}{L}+100 \times y\\
\frac{ab/l}{b}&=\frac{y}{4-3}\Rightarrow \frac{0.8}{4}=\frac{y}{1}=0.2m\\
BM_{max}&=200 \times 0.8+100 \times 0.2=180kNm

\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 19 The plane truss shown in the figure is subjected to an external force [latex]P[/latex]. It is given that [latex]P = 70 kN, a = 2 m,[/latex] and [latex]b = 3 m[/latex]. The magnitude (absolute value) of force (in kN) in member [latex]EF[/latex] is _______.
(round off to the nearest integer)
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}
\Sigma M_J&=0\\
V_A \times 8-H_A \times 1-70 \times 4&=0\\
8V_A-H_A&=280 \;\;\;(i)
\end{aligned}[/latex] To find [latex]H_A[/latex] (Cut the truss by 1-1) Consider left hand side [latex]\begin{aligned}
\Sigma M_E&=0\\
V_A \times 4-H_A \times 4&=0\\
V_A&=H_A \;\;\;(ii)\\
\text{using (i) and (ii)}&\\
8V_A-V_A&=280\\
7V_A&=280\\
V_A&=40kN\\
H_A&=40kN\\
H_J&=40kN\\
V_J&=70-40=30kN\\
\end{aligned}[/latex] To find force in member EF (Cit the truss by 2-2) Consider right hand side Force in member EF [latex]F_{EF}=V_J=30kN[/latex]

question: Question 21 A perfectly flexible and inextensible cable is shown in the figure (not to scale). The external loads at F and G are acting vertically. The magnitude of tension in the cable segment  FG (in  kN, round off to two decimal places) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_F=0\\ \left ( 10.667+\frac{H}{6} \right )2-H \times 3=0\\ H=8\; kN\\ V_E=10.667+\frac{8}{6}\\ V_E=12\; kN\\ V_H=10\; kN \end{aligned}[/latex] Consider left side of section (1)-(1) [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma H=0\\ T \cos \theta =H\\ T \cos \theta =8\\ T \sin \theta =2\\ \therefore \;\; T^2 \cos ^2\theta + T^2 \sin ^2 \theta =8^2+2^2\\ T=8.246\; kN \end{aligned}[/latex] Tension in segment GF is 8.246 kN.

question: Question 22 A prismatic fixed-fixed beam, modelled with a total lumped-mass of 10 kg as a single degree of freedom (SDOF) system is shown in the figure. If the flexural stiffness of the beam is [latex]4 \pi^{2} \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}[/latex], its natural frequency of vibration (in Hz, in integer) in the flexural mode will be _______
solution: Given Data: [latex]\begin{aligned} m&=10\; kg\\ K&=4 \pi^2 \times 10^3\\ &\text{Natural frequency,}\\ f_n&=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{k}{m}}\\ &=\frac{1}{2 \pi} \sqrt{\frac{4 \pi ^2 \times 10^3}{10}}\\ &=\frac{2 \pi \times 10}{2 \pi}=10 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 23 A frame EFG is shown in the figure. All members are prismatic and have equal flexural rigidity. The member FG carries a uniformly distributed load w per unit length. Axial deformation of any member is neglected. Considering the joint F being rigid, the support reaction at G is
solution: Compatibility condition [latex]\begin{array}{l} \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \frac{\partial U}{\partial R}=0 \\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \frac{\partial}{\partial R}\left[\int \frac{M^{2}}{2 E \mid} d x\right]=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{\partial}{\partial R}\left[\int_{0}^{L} \frac{\left(R x-\frac{w x^{2}}{2}\right)^{2}}{2 E I} d x+\int_{0}^{2 L} \frac{\left(R L-\frac{w L^{2}}{2}\right)^{2}}{2 E I} d x\right]=0 \\ \Rightarrow \int_{0}^{L} \frac{2\left(R x-\frac{w x^{2}}{2}\right)}{2 E I}(x) d x+\int_{0}^{2 L} \frac{\left(R L-\frac{w L^{2}}{2}\right)}{E I}(L) d x=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{R L^{3}}{3}-\frac{W}{2} \times \frac{L^{4}}{4}+R L^{2}(2 L)-\frac{W^{3}}{2}(2 L)=0 \\ \Rightarrow \frac{R L^{3}}{3}-\frac{w^{4}}{8}+2 R L^{3}-w L^{4}=0 \\ \Rightarrow 2 R L^{3}+\frac{R L^{3}}{3}=\frac{w^{4}}{8}+w^{4}=\frac{9}{8} w^{4} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{7 R L^{3}}{3}=\frac{9}{8} w L^{4} \\ \Rightarrow R=\frac{27}{56} w L=0.482 w L \end{array}[/latex] Alternative [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{w L^{4}}{8 E I}+\frac{w L^{2}(2 L)}{2 E I} \times L &=\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I}+\frac{R L \times 2 L \times L}{E I} \\ \frac{w^{4}}{8 E I}+\frac{w^{4}}{E I} &=\frac{R L^{3}}{3 E I}+\frac{2 R L^{3}}{E I} \\ \frac{9 W^{4}}{8 E I} &=\frac{7 R L^{3}}{3 E I} \\ R &=\frac{27 w L}{56}=0.482 \mathrm{wL} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 A propped cantilever beam XY, with an internal hinge at the middle, is carrying a uniformly distributed load of 10 kN/m, as shown in the figure. The vertical reaction at support X ( in kN, in integer) is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} B M &=0 \text { at hinge } \\ R_{Y} \times 2-10 \times 2 \times 1 &=0 \\ R_{Y} &=10 \mathrm{kN} \\ R_{X}+R_{Y} &=10 \times 4 \\ R_{X}+10 &=40 \\ R_{X} &=30 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 25 Employ stiffness matrix approach for the simply supported beam as shown in the figure to calculate unknown displacements/rotations. Take length, L=8 m; modulus of elasticity, [latex]E=3 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}[/latex]; moment of inertia, [latex]I=225 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{mm}^{4}[/latex]. The mid-span deflection of the beam (in mm,round off to integer) under P=100 kN in downward direction will be ___________
solution: By stiffness matrix method Step-1 : Generation of stiffness matrix Column-1 [latex]\begin{aligned} \mathrm{k}_{11}&=\frac{3 E(2 I)}{(L / 2)^{3}}+\frac{3 E(I)}{(L / 2)^{3}}=\frac{72 \mathrm{E} I}{L^{3}}\\ k_{21}&=-\frac{3 E(2 I)}{(L / 2)^{2}}+\frac{3 E(I)}{(L / 2)^{2}}=-\frac{12 E I}{L^{2}} \end{aligned}[/latex] Column-2 [latex]\begin{aligned} k_{22}&=\frac{3 E(2 I)}{(L / 2)}+\frac{3 E(I)}{(L / 2)}=18 \frac{E I}{L} \\ \text { Stiffness matrix }[k]&=\left[\begin{array}{cc} 72 \frac{E I}{L^{3}} & -\frac{12 E I}{L^{2}} \\ -\frac{12 E I}{L^{2}} & \frac{E I}{L} \end{array}\right] \end{aligned}[/latex] Step-2: Calculation of unknown Nodal displacements [latex]\left(\Delta_{\mathrm{B}}, \theta_{\mathrm{B}}\right)[/latex] [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{Using} \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad [P]&=[k][\Delta]\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \quad & \quad\left[\begin{array}{l} P \\ O \end{array}\right]=\left[\begin{array}{cc} \frac{72 E I}{L^{2}} & -\frac{12 E I}{L^{2}} \\ -\frac{12 E I}{L^{2}} & \frac{8 E I}{L} \end{array}\right]\left[\begin{array}{l} \Delta_{B} \\ \theta_{B} \end{array}\right]\\ \text{On solving} \qquad \qquad \qquad \quad\\\Delta_{\mathrm{B}}&=\frac{P L^{3}}{64 E I}(\downarrow) \\ \therefore \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \theta_{\mathrm{B}}&=\frac{P L^{2}}{96 E I}(\mathrm{CW}) \\ \Delta_{\mathrm{B}}&=\frac{\left(100 \times 10^{3}\right) \times(8000)^{3}}{64 \times 3 \times 10^{4} \times 225 \times 10^{6}}\\ &=118.519 \mathrm{~mm} \simeq 119 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 26 Refer the truss as shown in the figure (not to scale). If load, [latex]F=10 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{kN}[/latex], moment of inertia, [latex]I=8.33 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{~mm}^{4}[/latex], area of cross-section, [latex]A=10^{4} \mathrm{~mm}^{2}[/latex], and length, L=2 m for all the members of the truss, the compressive stress (in [latex]\mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2}[/latex],in integer) carried by the member Q-R is _________
solution: [latex]V_{P}=V_{S}=5 \sqrt{3} \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Considering equilibrium of LHS of section (1 )-(1) Taking moment about 'T' [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{T}(C W)&=0\\ (5 \sqrt{3} \times a)+F_{Q R}\left(\frac{\sqrt{3} a}{2}\right)&=0\\ \Rightarrow \qquad \qquad \qquad \qquad \quad F_{O A}&=-10 \mathrm{kN} or 10 \mathrm{kN} (C) \\ \text{ Compressive} &\text{ stress in member QR} \left(\sigma_{\mathrm{C}}\right)\\ \sigma_{\mathrm{C}}&=\frac{F_{Q A}}{2 A} \\ &=\frac{10 \mathrm{kN}}{2 \times\left(10^{4} \times 10^{-6}\right) \mathrm{m}^{2}} \\ &=500 \mathrm{kN} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 27 A truss EFGH is shown in the figure, in which all the members have the same axial rigidity R. In the figure, P is the magnitude of external horizontal forces acting at joints F and G. If [latex]R=500 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{kN}[/latex],[latex]P=150 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] and L=3 m, the magnitude of the horizontal displacement of joint G (in mm,round off to one decimal place) is ________
solution: Note: No need to calculate 'I< force in all members because 'P force is zero fore all members except FG By unit load method [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { 1. } \Delta_{\mathrm{HG}}=& \sum_{i=1}^{n} \frac{P_{i} k_{i} L_{i}}{A_{i} E_{i}} \\ \Delta_{\mathrm{HG}}=& \text { Horizontal deflection at joint } \mathrm{G} \\ \therefore \qquad & \qquad \qquad\Delta_{\mathrm{HG}} =\underbrace{\frac{P \times 1 \times L}{A E}}_{\text {FG-member }} \times \underbrace{Q^{\prime}}_{\text {(For all other members) }} \\ & \qquad \qquad\Delta_{\mathrm{HG}} =\frac{P L}{A E}=\left(\frac{150 \times 3}{500 \times 10^{3}} \times 10^{3}\right) \mathrm{mm} \\ & \qquad \qquad \qquad=0.90 \mathrm{~mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 The degree of static indeterminacy of the plane frame as shown in the figure is ___

question: Question 37 A portal frame shown in figure has a hinge support at joint P and a roller support at joint R. A point load of 50 kN is acting at joint R in the horizontal direction. The flexural rigidity, EI, of each member is 10 [latex]kNm^2[/latex]. Under the applied load, the horizontal displacement (in mm, round off to 1 decimal place) of joint R would be _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_p&=0\;\;[\text{Take clockwise as positive}]\\ R_R \times 5-50 \times 10&=0\\ R_R&=-100kN(\downarrow )\\ R_P&=100kN(\uparrow )\\ EI&=10^6kN-m^2\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Using unit load method: The horizontal displacement at 'R' [latex]\delta _{HR}=\int_{0}^{L}\frac{M_xm_x}{EI}dx[/latex] where [latex]M_x=[/latex] BM at X-X due to real loads [latex]m_x=[/latex] BM at X-X due to vertical unit load applied where we want to find the deflection. [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_R &=0\;\;[\text{Take clockwise as positive}]\\ R_P \times 5-1 \times 10&=0\\ R_P&=2kN(\uparrow )\end{aligned}[/latex] Sign conventions: Sagging +ve Hogging -ve [latex]\delta _{HR}=\int_{0}^{5}\frac{200x^2}{10^6}dx+\int_{0}^{10}\frac{50x^2}{10^6}dx=\frac{1}{40}=0.025m=25mm[/latex]

question: Question 38 The rigid-jointed plane frame QRS shown in the figure is subjected to a load P at the joint R. Let the axial deformations in the frame be neglected. If the support S undergoes a settlement of [latex]\Delta =\frac{PL^3}{\beta EI}[/latex], the vertical reaction at the support S will become zero when [latex]\beta[/latex] is equal to
solution: Adopting moment distribution method: Thus, fnal vertical reaction at S (both due [latex]f_0[/latex] sinking and P) [latex]\begin{aligned} R_S&=P-V \\ &= P-\frac{7.5EI}{L^3} \times \frac{PL^3}{\beta EI}\\ R_S&=\frac{P-7.5T}{\beta}\;\;\text{when}\; \beta =\text{ reaction at S = 0} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 Consider the pin-jointed plane truss shown in the figure. Let [latex]R_P,R_Q[/latex] and [latex]R_R[/latex] denote the vertical reactions (upward positive) applied by the supports at P, Q, and R, respectively, on the truss. The correct combination of ([latex]R_P,R_Q,R_R[/latex])is represented by
solution: Adopting method of sections and taking LHS of the section [latex]\begin{aligned} &\Sigma F_y= 0\\ &R_P=30kN \\ &\text{For complete truss,} \\ &\Sigma M_R =0 \\ &9R_P-30 \times 6 -R_Q \times 3=0 \\ &R_Q=30kN(\downarrow ) \\ &\text{Taking RHS of section,} \\ &\Sigma F_y=0\Rightarrow R_R=-R_Q \\ &\text{Thus},\;\; R_Q= 30kN(\downarrow )\\ &R_R=30kN(\uparrow ) \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 41 A prismatic beam P-Q-R of flexural rigidity [latex]EI=1\times 10^{4}kNm^{2}[/latex] is subjected to a moment of 180 kNm at Q as shown in the figure. The rotation at Q (in rad, up to two decimal places) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} K_{Q} &=K_{Q P}+K_{Q R} \\ &=\frac{4 E I}{5}+\frac{4 E I}{4}=1.8 \mathrm{EI} \\ \theta_{Q} &=\frac{M_{Q}}{K_{Q}}=\frac{180}{1.8 \times 10^{4}}=0.01 \mathrm{rad} \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternate solution [latex] \begin{aligned} &\begin{aligned} M_{Q P} &=M_{f Q P}+\frac{2 E I}{l}\left[2 \theta_{Q}+\theta_{P}\right] \\ &=\frac{4 \times 10^{4}}{5} \times \theta_{Q}=8000 \theta_{Q} \\ M_{Q R}=& M_{f Q R}+\frac{2 E I}{l}\left[2 \theta_{Q}+\theta_{R}\right] \\ & \quad\left\{M_{f Q R}=0, \theta_{R}=0\right\} \\ &=\frac{2 \times 10^{4}}{4}\left[2 \theta_{Q}\right]=10000 Q \\ \Sigma M_{Q} &=0 \end{aligned} \\ &\Rightarrow \quad M_{Q P}+M_{Q R}+180=0 \\ & \Rightarrow \quad 18000 \cdot \theta_{Q}=-180 \\ & \Rightarrow \quad \theta_{Q}=0.01 \;\text{radian (anticlockwise)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 44 Consider the deformable pin-jointed truss with loading, geometry and section properties as shown in the figure. Given that [latex]E =2 \times 10^{11} N/m^{2}[/latex], [latex]A = 10 mm^{2}[/latex], L = 1 m and P = 1 kN. The horizontal displacement of Joint C (in mm, up to one decimal place) is ______
solution: Force is each member due to applied loading [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{A B}&=P(\text { Comp. }) \\ F_{B C}&=3 P(\text { Comp. }) \\ F_{A C}&=\sqrt{2} P(\text { Tension }) \end{aligned}[/latex] Force in each member due to unit load. [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{A B}&=P(\text { Comp. }) \\ F_{B C}&=3 P(\text { Comp. }) \\ F_{A C}&=\sqrt{2} (\text { Tension }) \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} \therefore \text{ Total deflection }=\delta_{H_{c}}=\Sigma \frac{P k L}{A E} \\ =\frac{5.414 \times(1000 \mathrm{N}) \times(1000 \mathrm{mm})}{\left(10 \mathrm{mm}^{2}\right) \times\left(2 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{mm}^{2}\right)}=2.7 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 45 The figure shows a simply supported beam PQ of uniform flexural rigidity EI carrying two moments M and 2M. The slope at P will be
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \text { Now } \quad R_{1}+R_{2}=\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{L}{3} \times \frac{M}{E I}=\frac{M L}{6 E I} \\ \Sigma M_{O}=0 \\ R_{1} L-\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{L}{3} \times \frac{M}{E I}\left(\frac{2 L}{3}+\frac{L}{9}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{L}{3} \\ \times \frac{M}{E I}\left(\frac{L}{3}+\frac{L}{9}\right)+\frac{1}{2} \times \frac{L}{3} \times \frac{M}{E I} \times \frac{2 L}{9}=0\\ \quad R_{1}=\frac{7 M L}{54 E I}+\frac{4 M L}{54 E I}-\frac{M L}{27 E I}=\frac{M L}{6 E I} \\ \therefore \text{Slope at }P, \theta_{P}=R_{1}=\frac{M L}{6 E I} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 46 Consider the portal frame shown in the figure and assume the modulus of elasticity [latex]E=2.5\times 10^{4}[/latex] MPa and the moment of inertial, [latex]I=8\times 10^{8}\; mm^{4}[/latex] for all the members of the frame. question: Question 52 Consider the structural system shown in the figure under the action of weight W. All the joints are hinged. The properties of the members in terms of length (L), area (A) and the modulus of elasticity (E) are also given in the figure. Let L, A and E be 1 m, [latex]0.05m^{2}[/latex] and [latex]30\times 10^{6}N/m^{2}[/latex], respectively, and W be 100 kN. Which one of the following sets gives the correct values of the force, stress and change in length of the horizontal member QR?
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{array}{l} L=1 \mathrm{m}, A=0.05 \mathrm{m}^{2} \\ E=30 \times 10^{6} \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \end{array}[/latex] Consider joint 'S. [latex] \begin{aligned} & F_{\mathrm{SO}}=F_{\mathrm{SR}} \\ 2 F_{\mathrm{SQ}} \cos 45^{\circ}=& \mathrm{W} \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{\mathrm{SQ}}=& \frac{W}{2} \times \sqrt{2}=\frac{W}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \therefore \quad & F_{\mathrm{SO}}=\frac{W}{\sqrt{2}} \end{aligned} [/latex] As the truss is symmetrical, [latex] \therefore \quad F_{\mathrm{OP}}=F_{\mathrm{PR}}=\frac{W}{\sqrt{2}} \qquad \text{(Tensile)}[/latex] Now consider joint 'Q', [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{\mathrm{OP}}&=F_{\mathrm{OS}}=\frac{W}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \Sigma F_{x}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \frac{F_{Q P}}{\sqrt{2}}&+\frac{F_{\alpha S}}{\sqrt{2}}+F_{Q R}=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{\mathrm{QR}}&=\mathrm{W} &\text{(Compressive)}\\ \therefore \quad F_{\mathrm{OR}}&=100 \mathrm{kN} &\text{(Compressive)} \end{aligned}[/latex] Stress in member Q R, [latex]\begin{aligned} \sigma _{QR} &=\frac{F_{QR}}{2A} \\ \sigma _{QR} &=\frac{100}{2 \times 0.05} \\ \sigma _{QR}&=1000kN/m^2 \end{aligned}[/latex] As the member QR consist compressive tone, so, it will go under shortening. Sortening, [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta &=\frac{P(Length)}{2AE}=\frac{F_{QR}L_{QR}}{2AE}\\ L_{QR}&=\sqrt{L^2+L^2}=\sqrt{2}L\\ \therefore \;\; \Delta &=\frac{100 \times 10^3 \times \sqrt{2} \times 1}{2 \times 0.05 \times 30 \times 10^6}\\ &=\frac{100 \times 10^3 \times \sqrt{2}}{0.1 \times 30 \times 10^6}\\ &=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{30}\\ \therefore \;\; \Delta &=0.471 m \end{aligned}[/latex]

; Shortening = 0.0118 m

Question 55 Consider the plane truss with load P as shown in the figure. Let the horizontal and vertical reactions at the joint B be [latex]H_{B}[/latex] and [latex]V_{B}[/latex], respectively and [latex]V_{C}[/latex]  be the vertical reaction at the joint C. Which one of the following sets gives the correct values of [latex]V_{B}, H_{B}[/latex] and [latex]V_{C}[/latex] ?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{B}+V_{C} &=P &\ldots(i)\\ \Sigma M_{B} &=0\\ V_{C} \times 2 L-P \times 2 L&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{C}&=P \\ \text{From(i), }\quad V_{B}&=0 \\ \Sigma F_{x}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad H_{B}&=0 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 58 For the 2D truss with the applied loads shown below, the strain energy in the member XY is _______ kN-m. For member XY, assume AE = 30 kN, where A is cross-section area and E is the modulus of elasticity.
solution: First calculating reactions [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{A}&=0\\ \Rightarrow\quad R_{B} \times 3-10 \times 9-5 \times 3 &=0 \\ R_{B} &=35 \mathrm{kN} \\ H_{A} &=10 \mathrm{kN} \\ \Sigma M_{B} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad R_{A} \times 3+10 \times 9 &=0 \\ R_{A} &=-30 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let us cut a section 1-1 as shown in figure and consider the lower part. Given AE = 30 kN and L = 3 m. Calculation for force Pin XY member [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{\text {horizontal }} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{X Y}&=10 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Strain energy, [latex] \begin{aligned} U&=\frac{P^{2} L}{2 A E}\\ U &=\frac{10^{2} \times 3}{2 \times 30} \\ &=5 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 62 The static indeterminacy of the two-span continuous beam with an internal hinge,shown below,is_________

question: Question 63 For the truss shown below, the member PQ is short by 3 mm. The magnitude of vertical displacement of joint R (in mm) is _______________
solution: PQ is short by 3 mm We have to find out vertical displacement of joint R in mm, [latex] \Delta_{R}=\Sigma u(\lambda)[/latex] Let in apply unit load at R as shown below [latex] \begin{aligned} u_{P R} \sin \theta &=\frac{1}{2} \\ u_{P Q}+U_{P A} \cos \theta &=0 \\ u_{P O}=-U_{P R} \cos \theta &=-\frac{1}{2 \sin \theta} \cdot \cos \theta \\ u_{P O} &=-\frac{1}{2} \cot \theta \\ &=\frac{-1 \times 4 / 3}{2}=\frac{-2}{3} \\ \Delta_{R} &=u_{P O} \times \lambda_{P O} \\ &=\frac{-2}{3}(-3) \\ &=2 \mathrm{mm}\text{ upwards} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 64 Mathematical idealization of a crane has three bars with their vertices arranged as shown in the figure with a load of 80 kN hanging vertically. The coordinates of the vertices are given in parentheses. The force in the member QR, [latex]F_{QR}[/latex] will be
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{0}+V_{A} &=80 &\ldots(i)\\ \Sigma M_{R} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad 80 \times 3 &=V_{0} \times 2 \\ \therefore\quad V_{O} &=120 \mathrm{KN} \\ \Rightarrow\quad V_{R} &=-40 \mathrm{kN} \quad \text { From eq }(1) \\ \tan \phi &=\frac{1}{4} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \sin \phi &=\frac{1}{\sqrt{17}}, \cos \phi=\frac{4}{\sqrt{17}} \\ \therefore\quad \tan \theta &=\frac{3}{4} \\ \Rightarrow\quad \cos \theta &=\frac{4}{5} \end{aligned}[/latex] Consider joint Q [latex] \begin{aligned} \alpha &=104.03^{\circ}-90^{\circ}=14.03^{\circ} \\ \Sigma F_{y} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} \cos \alpha &=+V_{Q}=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} \cos 14.03^{\circ} &+120=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} &=-123.6897 \mathrm{kN} \\ \Sigma F_{x} &=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad F_{P Q} \sin \alpha &=F_{O R} \\ \therefore\quad F_{O R} &=-29.986 \mathrm{kN} \\ & \simeq 30 \mathrm{kNm}(\text { comp. }) \end{aligned}[/latex]

When unit load-is at T: Vertical reaction at P and Q equal to 0 [latex] \Sigma M_{0}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow \quad 1 \times 4&=R_{R} \times 20 \\ \therefore \quad R_{A}&=0.25 \mathrm{kN} \\ V_{O \text { (Righit) }}&=0.25 \mathrm{kN}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Now, if moving distributed load is present over span P R then we get maximum shear force just to the right of Q . question: Question 68 A uniform beam weighting 1800 N is supported at E and F by cable ABCD. Determine the tension (in N) in segment AB of this cable (correct to 1-decimal place). Assume the cable ABCD, BE and CF to be weightless. _____
solution: Taking moment about A, [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{D} \times 4 &=1800 \times 1.5 \\ \Rightarrow R_{D}&=675 \mathrm{N} \\ R_{A}= 1800-R_{D}&=1125 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex] At joint D, [latex] T_{\infty}=\frac{R_{D}}{\sin 45}=675 \sqrt{2} \mathrm{N}[/latex] Taking free body diagram as shown in figure, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma V &=0 \\ T_{A B} \sin \theta+675 \sqrt{2} \sin 45^{\circ} &=1800 \\ T_{A B} \sin \theta &=1125 &\ldots(i)\\ \Sigma H &=0 \\ T_{A B} \cos \theta &=675 \sqrt{2} \cos 45^{\circ} \\ \Rightarrow \quad T_{A B} \cos \theta &=675 &\ldots(ii)\\ \text{From} e q \cdot(i) \text { and }(i i) & \\ \tan \theta &=\frac{5}{3} \\ \sin \theta &=0.8575 \end{aligned}[/latex] Putting value of [latex]\sin \theta[/latex] in eq. (i) [latex] \begin{aligned} T_{A B} \times 0.8575 &=1125 \\ T_{A B} &=1311.96 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 70 The pin-jointed 2-D truss is loaded with a horizontal force of 15 kN at joint S and another 15 kN
vertical force at joint U, as shown. Find the force in member RS (in kN) and report your answer
taking tension as positive and compression as negative. __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{T}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow R_{v} \times 8-15 \times 4+15 \times 4 & =0 \\ \therefore \quad R_{V} & =0\\ \text{Take moment about V, } M_{V}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad R_{H} \times 4&=0 \\ \therefore \quad R_{H}&=0 \end{aligned} [/latex] We know that if two members meet at a joint which are not collinear and also there is no external forces acting on that joint then both members will carry zero forces. [latex] \therefore F_{O V}=F_{Q R}=0[/latex] Now, consider joint R , [latex] \Sigma F_{y}=0[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \Rightarrow F_{R U} \sin 45^{\circ}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow F_{R U}&=0\\ \text{Now},\quad \Sigma F_{x}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{R S}+F_{R U} \cos 45^{\circ}&=0 \\ \therefore F_{R S}&=0 \end{aligned} [/latex] So, force is member is "RS" will be zero.

question:
Question 71 A three hinged parabolic arch having a span of 20m and a rise of 5m carries a
point load of 10 kN at quarter span from the left end as shown in the figure. The
resultant reaction at the left support and its inclination with the horizontal are
respectively
solution: Let the vertical reactions at left and right support be [latex]V_{L}[/latex] and [latex]V_{R}[/latex] upwards respectively. Taking moments about right support, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{L} \times 20-10 \times 15&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{L}&=7.5 \mathrm{kN} \\ \therefore \quad V_{R}&=10-7.5=2.5 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let the horizontal reaction at left support be H from left to right. Taking moments about the crown from left, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} 7.5 \times 10-10 \times 5-H \times 5 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad H&=5 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Resultant reaction, [latex] \begin{aligned} R &=\sqrt{H^{2}+V_{L}^{2}} \\ &=\sqrt{5^{2}+(7.5)^{2}} \\ &=9.01 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Let the resultant reaction at the left support makes an angle [latex]\theta[/latex] with the horizontal. [latex] \begin{aligned} & \tan \theta=\frac{7.5}{5} \\ \Rightarrow & \theta=\tan ^{-1}(1.5) \\ \Rightarrow & \theta=56.31^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 72 For the truss shown in the figure, the force in the member QR is
solution: Using method of joints and considering joint S, we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{x}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{T S}&=0\\ \text{and }\quad \Sigma F_{y}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow F_{R S}-P&=0 \\ \Rightarrow F_{R S}&=P(\text { tensile }) \end{aligned} [/latex] Considering joint R, we get [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma F_{v}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad-F_{I R} \sin 45^{\circ}-P&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{I R}&=-P \sqrt{2} \text{(compressive)}\\ \Sigma F_{x}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad-F_{T R} \cos 45^{\circ}-F_{Q R}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad P \sqrt{2} \times \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-F_{\alpha R}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{Q R}&=P\text{(tension)} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 73 The degree of static indeterminacy of rigidity jointed frame in a horizontal plane
and subjected to vertical load only, as shown in figure below, is
solution: In general, total number of equilibrium equations for a 3-D rigidly jointed frame are 6. i.e. [latex] \Sigma F_{x}=0, \Sigma F_{y}=0, \Sigma F_{2}=0, \Sigma M_{x}=0, \Sigma M_{y}=0 [/latex] [latex] \Sigma M_{z}=0 [/latex] But for vertical loading, these equilibrium equations reduces to 3. I.e. [latex]\Sigma F_{y}=0, \Sigma M_{x}=0\text{ and }\Sigma M_{z}=0 [/latex] Also, at fixed support in a 3 -D rigidly jointed frame total number of external reactions are 6 i.e.. [latex] R_{x^{\prime}}, R_{y^{\prime}} R_{z^{\prime}} M_{x^{\prime}} M_{y^{\prime}} M_{z}[/latex] But for vertical loading, these external reactions reduce to 3 i.e., [latex] R_{y^{\prime}} M_{x^{\prime}} M_{z}[/latex] Thus for two fixed supports total external reactions will be 6 [latex] \therefore [/latex] Degree of static indeterminacy = Total external reactions - Total number of available equilibrium equations [latex] =6-3=3[/latex]

question: Question 76 The degree of static indeterminacy of the rigid frame having two internal hinges as shown in the figure below, is
solution: The degree of static indeterminacy for a rigid hybrid frame is given by, [latex] \begin{aligned} D_{s} &=3 m+r_{e}-r_{r}-3(j+7) \\ \text { Where, } m &=\text { total number of members }=9 \\ r_{e} &=\text { total number of external reactions } \\ &=2+1+1=4\\ r_{r}&= \text{total number of released reactions at }\\ &\text{hybrid joint}\\ &=\Sigma\left(m_{j}-1\right)=(2-1)+(2-1)=2 \\ j &=\text { total number of rigid joints }=6 \\ j &=\text { total number of hybrid joints }=2 \\ \therefore \quad D_{S} &=(3 \times 9)+4-2-3(6+2) \\ &=27+4-2-24=31-26=5 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 77 A two span continuous beam having equal spans each of length L is subjected to
a uniformly distributed load w per unit length. The beam has constant flexural
rigidity. The bending moment at the middle support is
solution: Let reaction at A and B be [latex]R_{A}[/latex] and [latex]R_{B}[/latex] , then as the beam is symmetrically loaded, the reaction [latex]R_{A}[/latex] and [latex]R_{B}[/latex] will be equal. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad R_{A}=R_{B} &=\frac{w \times 2 L-\frac{5 w L}{4}}{2} \\ &=\frac{8 m-5 w}{4 \times 2}=\frac{3 w L}{8} \\ \text { Thus, } \quad B M_{C} &=\frac{3}{8} w L \times L-w \times L \times \frac{L}{2}=\frac{w L^{2}}{8} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 78 A two span continuous beam having equal spans each of length L is subjected to
a uniformly distributed load w per unit length. The beam has constant flexural
rigidity. The reaction at the middle support is
solution: Removing support C, we get deflection at C as [latex] \delta_{c}=\frac{5}{384} \times \frac{m(2 L)^{4}}{E I}(\downarrow)[/latex] Let reaction at support C is R, then considering only R, we get deflection at C as, [latex] \delta_{c}^{\prime}=\frac{R(2 L)^{3}}{48 E I}(\uparrow)[/latex] For no deflection at C, [latex] \begin{aligned} \delta_{c}-\delta_{c}^{\prime}&=0\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{5}{384} \times \frac{m(2 L)^{4}}{E I}&=\frac{R \times(2 L)^{3}}{48 E I} \\ \Rightarrow R=\frac{5}{384} \times 48 w \times 2 L&=\frac{5 w L}{4} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 80 The right triangular truss is made of members having equal cross sectional area of 1550 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex] and Young's modulus of [latex]2\times 10^{5}[/latex] MPa. The horizontal deflection of the joint Q is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} H_{R}-135 &=0 \\ H_{R} &=135 \mathrm{kN} \\ \tan \theta &=\frac{6}{4.5} \\ \sin \theta=& \frac{6}{7.5} ; \cos \theta=\frac{4.5}{7.5} \\ \text{Taking} \quad \Sigma M_{R}&=0 \\ \Rightarrow-V_{P} \times 4.5+135 \times 6 &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad & V_{P}=180 \mathrm{kN} \\ \therefore \quad & V_{R}=-180 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex]\begin{array}{ll} \Sigma F_{y}=0 & \Sigma F_{x}=0 \\ F_{R Q}-180=0 & F_{P O} \cos \theta-135=0 \\ F_{R Q}=180 \mathrm{kN} & F_{P Q}=\frac{135 \times 7.5}{4.5} \\ \text { and } \Sigma F_{x}=0 & F_{P Q}=225 \mathrm{kN} \\ F_{R P}-135=0 & \\ F_{R P}=135 \mathrm{kN} \end{array}[/latex] Tension (+); compression (-) and [latex]K=\frac{P}{135}[/latex] for each member, [latex]\begin{aligned} \delta_{0} &=\Sigma \frac{P K L}{A E} \\ &=\frac{2818.125+1436.4+607.5}{A E} \\ &=\frac{4862.025 \times 10^{-6} \times 10^{3}}{1550 \times 10^{-6} \times 2 \times 10^{5} \times 10^{-3}} \\ &=15.68 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 81 The stiffness coefficient [latex]k_{ij}[/latex] indicates

question: Question 82 Carry-over factor [latex]C_{AB}[/latex] for the beam shown in the figure below is
solution: Applying a moment M at A . Let reaction at A and B is [latex]V_{A}[/latex] and [latex]V_{B}[/latex] respectively, and carryover moment be [latex]M_{B}. [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Taking }M_{c}&=0 \quad \text{(from left) }\\ V_{A} \times L-M &=0 \\ \Rightarrow_{A} &=\frac{M}{L} \\ \therefore V_{B}&=-\frac{M}{L} \\ \text{Now, taking }M_{C}&=0 \text{ from right,}\\ M_{B}-V_{B} \times L &=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad M_{B} &=\left(\frac{-M}{L}\right) \times L \\ M_{B} &=-M \\ \text { Carryover factor } &=\frac{\mid \text { Carryover moment } \mid}{\mid \text { Applied moment } \mid} \\ \Rightarrow &=\frac{M}{M}=1 \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 84 A truss is shown in the figure. Members are to equal cross section A and same
modulus of elasticity E. A vertical force P is applied at point C. Deflection of the point C is
solution: It is evidence from the diagram that all the interior members will carry zero force. Assuming tensile forces as positive and compressive forces as negative Deflection at C, [latex]\delta_{c}=\Sigma \frac{P K L}{A E} [/latex] Where K is the force in member when a unit load is applied at C. [latex] \begin{aligned} &=\frac{P L}{\sqrt{2} A E}+\frac{P L}{\sqrt{2} A E}+\frac{P L}{2 A E}\\ &=\frac{\sqrt{2} P L+\sqrt{2} P L+P L}{2 A E} \\ &=\left(\frac{2 \sqrt{2}+1}{2}\right) \frac{P L}{A E} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 85 A truss is shown in the figure. Members are to equal cross section A and same
modulus of elasticity E. A vertical force P is applied at point C. Force in the member AB of the truss is
solution: since the truss is loaded symmetrically, the reactions will be equal. Thus reaction at [latex]B=R_{B}=\frac{P}{2} [/latex] Now considering joint equilibrium at B. [latex] \begin{aligned} \because \quad \Sigma F_{y}&=0 \\ F_{B D} \sin \theta+\frac{P}{2}&=0 \;\;\;\ldots(i)\\ \because \quad \Sigma F_{x}&=0 \\ F_{B D} \cos \theta+F_{A B}&=0 \;\;\;\ldots(ii)\\ \text{From (i), we have}\\ F_{BD} &=-\frac{P}{2 \sin 45^{\circ}}=\frac{-P}{\sqrt{2}} \\ \therefore \quad F_{A B}&=-F_{BD} \cos \theta \\ &=-\left(\frac{-P}{\sqrt{2}}\right) \times \cos 45^{\circ}=\frac{P}{2} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 86 All members of the frame shown below have the same flexural rigidity EI and
length L. If a moment M is applied at joint B, the rotation of the joint is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text{For }A B, \quad \theta_{B}&=\frac{M L}{4 E I} \\ \Rightarrow \text{ Stiffness at }\quad B&=\frac{4 E I}{L} \\ \text{For }B C \theta_{B}&=\frac{M L}{3 E I} \\ \Rightarrow \text{Stiffness at }\quad B&=\frac{3 E I}{L}\\ \text{For }BD, \quad \theta_{B}&=\frac{M L}{4 E I} \\ \Rightarrow \text{ Stiffness at }\quad B&=\frac{4 E I}{L} \\ \text{Total stiffness of }&\text{the joint}\\ =\frac{4 E I}{L}+\frac{3 E I}{L}+\frac{4 E I}{L}&=\frac{11 E I}{L} \\ \text{Rotation of joint }B&=\frac{M L}{11 E I} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 90 The plane frame below is analyzed by neglecting axial deformations. Following
statements are made with respect to the analysis : I. Column AB carries axial force only II. Vertical Deflection at the center of beam BC is 1 mm With reference to the above statements, which of the following applies?
solution: Let reaction at A and B be [latex]R_{A}[/latex] and [latex]R_{B}[/latex] respectively. Taking moments about D , we get, [latex] \begin{aligned} R_{A} \times 5-10 \times 5 &\times 2.5=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad R_{A}&=25 \mathrm{kN}\\ \therefore \quad R_{B}&=(10 \times 5)-25=25 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Since reaction [latex]R_{A}[/latex] and [latex]R_{D}[/latex] are equal and no horizontal reaction so beam BC will behave as a simply supported beam. Deflected shape is as shown below. Thus deflection at the centre of beam [latex] \begin{array}{l} =\frac{5}{384} \frac{w^{4}}{E I} \\ =\frac{5}{384} \times \frac{10 \times(5)^{4}}{81380} \times 10^{3} \\ =1.00 \mathrm{mm} \end{array}[/latex] Column AB will carry only axial force equal to [latex]R_{A}[/latex] i.e. 25kN

options.B: Statement I is true but II is false
options.C: Statement II is true but I is false

question:
Question 91 A three hinged parabolic arch ABC has a span of 20 m and a central rise of 4 m.
The arch has hinges at the ends and at the centre. A train of two point loads of
20 kN and 10 kN, 5m apart, crosses this arch from left to right, with 20 kN load
leading. The maximum thrust induced at the supports is
solution: In case of a three hinged parabolic arch, the influence line diagram for horizontal thrust is linear. Maximum thrust will be induced at the supports when 20 kN load is at the crown. Ordinate of the ILD at a distance of 5 m from [latex] A=\frac{5}{10} \times \frac{L}{4 h}=\frac{1}{2} \times\left(\frac{20}{4 \times 4}\right)=0.625 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] also [latex]\frac{L}{4 h}=\frac{20}{4 \times 4}=1.25 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] Thus, horizontal thrust. [latex] H=10 \times 0.625+20 \times 1.25=31.25 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question:
Question 92 For the plane frame with an overhang as shown below, assuming negligible axial
deformation, the degree of static indeterminacy, d, and the degree of kinematic
indeterminacy, k, are
solution: Static indeterminacy, [latex]D=D_{s \theta}+D_{s i} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{where, }D_{s \theta}&=\text{ external static indeterminacy }\\ D_{s i} &=\text { internal static indeterminacy } \\ \text { alsp. } D_{s e} &=r_{\theta}-3 \\ &\quad \left[\because r_{\theta}=\right.\text { total external reactions }] \\ &=3+2+1-3=3 \\ \text { and } & D_{s i}=3 C \\ &\quad[\because C=\text { total number of closed loops }] \\ &=3 \times 2=6 \\ \therefore \quad D_{s} &=3+6=9 \end{aligned}[/latex] Alternatively, [latex] \begin{aligned} D_{s} &=3 m+r_{e}-3 \mathrm{j} \\ m &=\text { total members }=11 \\ r_{e} &=\text { total external reactions } \\ &=3+2+1=6 \\ j &=\text { total number of joints }=10 \\ \therefore \quad D_{s} &=(3 \times 11)+6-(3 \times 10)=9 \end{aligned}[/latex] Kinematic indeterminacy, [latex] k=\left(3 j-r_{e}\right)-m^{\prime} [/latex] where [latex]m^{\prime}=[/latex] total number of axially rigid members. [latex] \Rightarrow \quad k=(3 \times 10-6)-11=13[/latex]

question: Question 93 For a linear elastic structural system, minimization of potential energy yields
solution:
In a linear elastic structural system for potential 
energy (U) to be minimum, [latex]
\frac{\partial U}{\partial P}=0[/latex] The above equation represents the compatibility 
condition at the point where load P is acting.

question: Question 94 The unit load method used in structural analysis is
solution: Unit load method is used to find deflection at any point of structure. It is derived from Castigliano's theorem. [latex] \Delta=\frac{\partial U}{\partial Q}=\int M \frac{\partial M}{\partial Q} \frac{d x}{E I}=\int \frac{M m d x}{E I}[/latex]

options.A: applicable only to statically indeterminate structures
options.C: an extension of Maxwell's reciprocal theorem

question:
Question 95 For the plane truss shown in the figure, the number of zero force members for the
given loading is
solution:
If three members meet at a joint and two of them 
are collinear, then the third member will carry zero 
force provided that there is no external load at the 
joint. Thus using above statement we arrive at 
8 zero force members which are highlighted by 
'o' sign.

question:
Question 96 A beam PQRS is 18 m long and is simply supported at points Q and R, 10 m apart.
Overhangs PQ and RS are 3 m and 5 m respectively. A train of two point loads of
150 kN and 100kN, 5 m apart, crosses this beam from left to right with 100 kN load leading. The maximum hogging moment in the beam anywhere is
solution:
Maximum hogging BM will be at support R because 
overhang is maximum on that side. ILD for hogging 
BM at R is, Maximum hogging moment in the beam occurs 
when 150 kN load is at S. BM at S [latex]= -150 \times 5 = -750 kNm[/latex]

question:
Question 97 A beam PQRS is 18 m long and is simply supported at points Q and R, 10 m apart.
Overhangs PQ and RS are 3 m and 5 m respectively. A train of two point loads of
150 kN and 100kN, 5 m apart, crosses this beam from left to right with 100 kN load leading. During the passage of the loads, the maximum and the minimum reactions at
support R, in kN, are respectively
solution: ILD for reaction at R is given as Maximum reaction at R will occur when 100 kN load is at S [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{R(\max )} &=100 \times 1.5+150 \times 1 \\ &=150+150=300 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Minimum reaction at R will occur when 100 kN load is at P [latex] V_{R(\min )}=-100 \times 0.3=-30 \mathrm{kN}[/latex]

question:
Question 98 A beam PQRS is 18 m long and is simply supported at points Q and R, 10 m apart.
Overhangs PQ and RS are 3 m and 5 m respectively. A train of two point loads of
150 kN and 100kN, 5 m apart, crosses this beam from left to right with 100 kN load leading. The maximum sagging moment under the 150 kN load anywhere is
solution:
Maximum sagging bending moment under 150 kN 
load occurs when 150 kN load and resultant of 
150 kN and 100 kN are located equidistant from 
the centre of span. In other words, when the 
centre of beam lies midway between the resultant 
and the load under consideration, maximum 
sagging moment occurs under the load under 
consideration [latex]\begin{aligned} (150+100)\bar{x} &=150 \times 0 +100 \times 5 \\ \bar{x}&=2m \\ \therefore \;\; \frac{ab}{L} &= \frac{4 \times 6}{10}= 2.4 \end{aligned}[/latex] Ordinate under 100 kN load [latex]= \frac{2.4}{6}\times 1= 0.4[/latex] Therefore, sagging BM under 150 kN load [latex]= 2.4 \times 150+ 0.4 \times 100=400 kN-m[/latex]

question:
Question 99 A truss, as shown in the figure, is carrying 180 kN load at node [latex]L_2[/latex]. The force in
the diagonal member [latex]M_2U_4[/latex] will be
solution:
Let reactions at [latex]L_{0}[/latex] and [latex]L_{6}[/latex] be [latex] R_{L_{0}} [/latex] and [latex]R_{L_{6}}[/latex] respectively. [latex]
 \therefore R_{L_{0}}+R_{L_{6}}=180 \qquad\ldots(i)[/latex] Taking moments about [latex]L_{0}[/latex] , we get, [latex]
R_{L_{6}} \times 24-180 \times 8=0 [/latex] [latex]
 \Rightarrow \quad R_{L_{6}}=60 \mathrm{kN} [/latex] [latex]
 \therefore [/latex]From (i), we get, [latex]
 R_{L_{0}}=120 \mathrm{kN} [/latex] Assuming a section passing through members [latex]
U_{3} U_{4}, M_{2} L_{3}[/latex] and [latex]L_{3} L_{4}[/latex] and considering left portion Taking moments about [latex]L_{3}=0 [/latex] [latex]
 \Rightarrow 120 \times 12-180 \times 4+F_{U_{3}} u_{4} \times 3=0 [/latex] [latex]
 \Rightarrow F_{U_{3} U_{4}}=-240 \mathrm{kN}=240 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] (compression) Now assuming a section passing through 
members [latex]U_{3} U_{4}, M_{2} U_{4}, M_{2} L_{4}[/latex] and [latex]L_{3} L_{4}[/latex] and considering right portion. [latex]\cos \theta=\frac{3}{5} ; \sin \theta=\frac{4}{5} [/latex] Taking moments about [latex]L_{4}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{l} F_{U_{3} U_{4}} \times 3-\left(F_{M_{2} U_{4}} \sin \theta\right) \times 3-60 \times 8=0 \\ \Rightarrow \quad 240 \times 3-480=F_{M_{2} U_{4}} \times 3 \times \frac{4}{5} \\ \Rightarrow \quad F_{M_{2} U_{4}}=100 \mathrm{kN} (tension) \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 100 In a redundant joint model, three bar members are pin connected at Q as shown
in the figure. Under some load placed at Q, the elongation of the members MQ
and OQ are found to be 48 mm and 35 mm respectively. Then the horizontal
displacement 'u' and the vertical displacement 'v' of the node Q, in mm, will be
respectively,
solution: [latex]\text { Let } \angle M Q N=\theta_{1} \text { and } \angle O Q N=\theta_{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \tan \theta_{1}&=\frac{M N}{N Q}=\frac{400}{500}=0.8 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \theta_{1}&=0.625 \\ \text{ and }\cos \theta_{1}&=0.781 \\ \text{and }\tan \theta_{2}&=\frac{N O}{N Q}=\frac{500}{500}=1 \\ \Rightarrow \quad \sin \theta_{2}&=0.707 \\ \text{ and }\cos \theta_{2}&=0.707 \\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Elongation of member MQ in terms of u and v will be, [latex] \begin{aligned} u \sin \theta_{1}+v \cos \theta_{1}&=48 \\ \text{or, }0.625 u+0.781 v&=48 \quad &\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Elongation of member OQ in terms of u and v will be, [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{or, }-u \sin \theta_{2}+v \cos \theta_{2}&=35 \\ -0.707 u+0.707 v&=35 \quad \ldots(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] Solving (i) and (ii) we get, [latex] u=6.64 \mathrm{mm}\text{ and }v=56.14 \mathrm{mm}[/latex]

question:
Question 101 The stiffness K of a beam deflecting in a symmetric mode, as shown in the figure,
is
solution: The beam will deflect in symmetric mode when a constant moment M is applied at both ends. Slope at either ends will be given as [latex]\frac{M L}{2 E I}[/latex]. We know that stiffness is the moment required to produce unit slope. [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \theta&=\frac{M L}{2 E I} \\ \Rightarrow \quad M&=\frac{2 E I}{L} \theta &[\because \theta=1]\\ \Rightarrow \quad M&=\frac{2 E I}{L}=K \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 102 Muller Breslau's principle in structural analysis is used for
solution:
Muller Breslau's principle is a principle on the 
basis of which it is possible to draw influence lines 
for various quantities pertaining to a structure. It 
states that: "The ordinates of the influence lines for any stress 
element (such as axial stress, moment or reaction) 
of any structure are proportional to those of deflection 
curve, which is obtained by removing the restraint 
corresponding to that element from the structure and 
introducing in its place a deformation into the primary 
structure which remains."

options.A: drawing influence line diagram for any force function

question: Question 103 The end moment (in kNm units) developed in the roof level beams in the laterally loaded frame shown below (with all columns having identical cross-sections) according to the Cantilever Method of simplified analysis, is
solution:
According to cantilever method, point of 
contraflexure lies at mid point of each span and 
direct stresses (axial) in column due to horizontal 
forces are directly proportional to their distance 
from the centroidal vertical axis of frame. [latex]\overline{h}[/latex] = CG of frame will be at mid column due to 
symmetry. [latex]
\overline{h}=\frac{1\times0+2\times6+1\times12}{3}=6m[/latex] Since, areas of each column are equal so axial force in each column will be in proportional to their distance from CG . [latex] \frac{V_{1}}{x_{1}}=\frac{V_{3}}{x_{3}}[/latex] As distance of [latex]V_{2}[/latex] from C G=0 [latex] \therefore \quad V_{2}=0 [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{V_{1}}{6}&=\frac{V_{3}}{6}\\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{1}&=V_{3} \end{aligned}[/latex] Take moment about L [latex] \begin{aligned} 30 \times 2 &=V_{1} \times 12 \\ V_{1} &=5 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] and from equilibrium of forces end moment at roof level beam [latex]=7.5 \times 2=15 \mathrm{kNm}[/latex]

question:
Question 104 Identify, from the following, the correct value of the bending moment [latex]M_A[/latex] (in kNm units) at the fixed end A in the statically determinate beam shown below (with internal hinges at B and D), when a uniformly distributed load of 10 kN/m is placed on all spans. (Hint: Sketching the influence line for [latex]M_A[/latex] or applying the
Principle of Virtual Displacements makes the solution easy).
solution: ILD for BM at A by using Muller Breslau principle will be [latex] \begin{aligned} M_{A}&=\text { Net area of } 1 L D \times 10 \\ M_{A}&=\left[-\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 4\right)+\left(\frac{1}{2} \times 2 \times 4\right)\right] \times 10=0 \mathrm{kNm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 105 The frame below shows three beam elements OA, OB and OC, with identical
length L and flexural rigidity El , subject to an external moment M applied
at the rigid joint O. The correct set of bending moments [latex]\{M_{OA},M_{OB},M_{OC}\}[/latex], that
develop at O in the three beam elements OA, OB and OC respectively, is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} M_{O A} &=M \times D F \text { for } O A \\ &=M \times \frac{3}{7}=\frac{3}{7} M\\ M_{O B} &=0 \\ M_{O C} &=M \times D F \text { for } O C \\ &=M \times \frac{4}{7}=\frac{4}{7} M \end{aligned} [/latex]

question: Question 109 The degree of static indeterminacy, [latex]N_s[/latex], and the degree of kinematic indeterminacy, [latex]N_k[/latex] , for the plane frame shown below, assuming axial deformations to be negligible, are given by
solution: Degree of static indeterminacy, [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{s} &=3 m+r_{e}-3 j-r_{r} \\ &=3 \times 5+(3+2+2)-3 \times 6-0 \\ &=4 \end{aligned}[/latex] Degree of kinematic indeterminacy, [latex] \begin{aligned} N_{k} &=3 j-r_{e}-m \\ &=3 \times 6-(3+2+2)-5=6 \\ N_{s} &=4 \text { and } N_{k}=6 \end{aligned}[/latex]
